revised_title: Antagonism between Natural Selection and Sexual Selection in Chlamydomonas
tldr: The study investigates the relationship between mating efficiency and vegetative growth rate in the unicellular, facultatively sexual alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. By selecting for mating efficiency and measuring the correlated response in vegetative growth rate, the researchers found a negative genetic correlation between fitness components, as predicted by life-history theory. This demonstrates a net viability cost of sexual selection.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Genetics and Evolution
